question.title: What special characters does Lucene StandardQueryParser use?
question.body:
When user strings are submitted to Lucene's StandardQueryParser.parse, the parser will sometimes throw an exception because the string includes special characters in unexpected ways (e.g. search for "Wham!").

Lucene documented the list of special characters for the old QueryParser. But the new, preferred StandardQueryParser includes some new special characters, such as =.

What are these characters? Are they documented anywhere? (I have not been able to locate any comprehensive list.) I would like to simply remove such characters from queries that cause parse exceptions (not all users can be expected to submit well-formed queries in the wild).

To reiterate, I am asking about StandardQueryParser not QueryParser.

question_comments.body: "I thought I made that pretty clear, apparently not." If that is addressed to me, rest assured it was already clear to me from your question.

That QueryParserUtil class I mentioned in my comments is not for the classic query parser. It is for the query parser your question is discussing. The "classic" query parser has its own separate escape() method, also. Note how that is in the org.apache.lucene.queryparser.classic package. The escape() method in my earlier comments is in the org.apache.lucene.queryparser.flexible.standard package. Note the difference between "classic" and "standard".
I have added a note for other folks who do not absorb from my question that QueryParser is not the same as StandardQueryParser. I thought I made that pretty clear, apparently not.

@andrewJames, no that is the util class for the old QueryParser class referenced in my question. As I said in the question, I am using a different class, StandardQueryParser. It is trivial to find the special character list for QueryParser with a Google search, unfortunately not so trivial for StandardQueryParser
@VGR agreed. I assumed it was implicit. Still for the quality of the question the OP should reword it that why.

@aled That is technically true, but if this question were phrased as "What are the special characters in the query passed to StandardQueryParser.parse" it would be valid.  That is how I essentially read it.
Asking for off-site resources is off topic.
